Award.AbstractNarration:
Larson proposes work on five related topics, all centering around the extent to which the absoluteness results and detailed analysis of inner models of determinacy in the context of large cardinals can be lifted to larger models satisfying larger fragments of the Axiom of Choice. One topic is the so-called universally measurable sets, where the fundamental open question is whether all such sets can have the property of Baire. One topic concerns the fragment of the Axiom of Choice which holds when a model of determinacy is expanded by adding a Ramsey ultrafilter. Another concerns lifting to the third uncountable cardinal Woodin's results on getting forcing axioms at the second uncountable cardinal by forcing over a determinacy model. The fourth concerns application of techniques from set theory to Shelah's study of Abstract Elementary Classes. Finally, Larson proposes to study ideals on the first uncountable cardinal from the point of view of certain inner models satisfying a small fragment of Choice.

The standard axioms for set theory, the Zermelo-Fraenkel axioms, serve as the commonly accepted foundations for mathematics, though as mathematics becomes more abstract, more and more issues arise which are not resolved by these axioms. Many of these issues are studied by set theorists, in hope of finding the right extension of these axioms. Developments in the study of such possible extensions have had a dramatic foundational impact in the last thirty years, affecting many areas of mathematics, and even philosophy. The PI works on the border between some of the more technical, inward-directed areas of set theory and more classical areas with connections to other fields. Much of his work consists of finding applications of these more technical areas, and exposing them to a wider audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied the relationship between the more abstract areas of mathematics used in foundational work and more concrete topics used in more applied areas. The project covered a wide variety of topics in set theory and model theory, and involved collaboration with several researchs in the US and abroad. It resulted in more than 10 journal articles, two book chapters and one book co-edited by the PI. 

The central concerns of the project had to do with the relative definability of mathematical objects which require nonconstructive principles, such as the Axiom of Choice, to establish their existence. Somce of the central results include the following. 

1. A method (developed in collaboration with Jindrich Zapletal of the Unversity of Florida) for studying canonical models for fragements of the Axiom of Choice, and using these models to prove non-implication results between them. 

2. A study (with five authors, partially supported through the Squares program at the American Institute of Mathematics) of models built from strong forms of the Axiom of Determinacy, leading to improved lower bounds for consistency results, and the development of new forms of determinacy. 

3. An axiomatization of the Scott analysis, a technique from infinitary logic for characterizing mathematical structures. This method enables uniform proofs of a number of classical results on Vaught's Conjecture, which is one of the major open problems in model theory. 

4. A thorough study (with three co-authors) of a notion of universal function inspired by a question from the Scottish Book (an influential and foundation body of mathematics deriving mostly from work in Poland in the early 20th century). 

5. Several papers with Saharon Shelah (of Rutgers Univesity and the Hebrew University of Jerusalem) and other coauthors on topics in set theory and model theory, some with possible applications to group theory. These include  coding results in set theory, set theory of the real line, combinatorics and abstract elementary classes. 

6. Work with Dilip Raghavan of the Univesity of Singapore on the possible existence of definable coideals, extending classical results of Adrian Mathias. 

7. Work with five coauthors on set-theoretic aspects of conditionally convergent series in finite dimensional Banach spaces, leading both to new questions in the theory of cardinal characteristics of the continuum and new proofs of classical results.
